chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: This chapter provides a brief introduction to &PRODUCT; and its usage, and covers how to create, configure, manage, and build a full-featured blog.

note.para: On GNU/Linux, UNIX, and similar operating systems, you can use blaze-command and more convenient blaze command interchangeably. For a list of available commands, type the following at a shell prompt:

example.title: Creating a New Blog in the ~/public_html/ Directory
example.para: Many web servers are able to serve content from a certain directory within user's home directory, typically ~/public_html/. You can start a new blog in this directory by typing the following command:
example.screen: public_html]$ blaze-init Created a BlazeBlogger repository in .blaze.

section.title: Configuring a Blog
section.para: In an attempt to make complex changes to the configuration as painless as possible, &PRODUCT; is shipped with a utility to help you with this task. To display the current value of a particular configuration option, use the blaze-config command followed by an option name:
To change a configuration option, supply the new value:
section.screen: blaze-config option value…
section.para: &PRODUCT; also allows you to edit all available options at once in an external text editor. To do so, run the blaze-config command with the --edit (or -e) command line option:
Note that unless the core.editor configuration option is already set, you must also specify a text editor to use by adding the --editor (or -E) option:
The rest of this section tries to cover the most common configuration tasks, and by no means serves as a full reference. For a complete list of available configuration options, refer to .

section.title: General Blog Settings
section.para: In order for web browsers to correctly determine the character encoding of a blog, each web page must include an appropriate information in its header. To change this information, update the core.encoding option with a value in the form that is recognized by W3C standards:

Keep in mind that this option must match the character encoding you use to write the content. &PRODUCT; does not change the encoding on its own, nor does it check the value you provided. The default option is UTF-8.
To select the document type of the generated pages, use the following command:
Allowed options are html for HTML and xhtml for the XHTML standard. For compatibility reasons, the default option is to generate HTML pages.
Finally, to change the file extension of the generated pages, run:
The changes will take effect the next time you build the blog with the blaze-make command.

example.title: Changing the Blog Encoding
example.para: In most cases, the use of UTF-8 is recommended. However, if you write your blog in other encoding such as ISO-8859-2 (that is, Latin-2), type:
example.screen: public_html]$ blaze-config core.encoding ISO-8859-2 The option has been successfully saved.

section.title: Configuring an RSS Feed
section.para: To enable the creation of an RSS feed with the syndication of blog updates, supply a valid URL with the location of the blog, making sure that you include the http:// (or https:// if you use a secure protocol) prefix:
The feed will be created the next time you build the blog with the blaze-make command.

example.title: Enabling the Creation of an RSS Feed
example.para: To enable an RSS feed for a blog located at http://blaze.blackened.cz/, type the following at a shell prompt:
example.screen: public_html]$ blaze-config feed.baseurl http://blaze.blackened.cz/ The option has been successfully saved.

section.title: Changing the Blog Title
section.para: To change the title of the blog, use the following command:
Beside this option, &PRODUCT; also allows you to specify the subtitle. This is typically a brief description of the blog, or a motto. To change the blog subtitle, run:
The changes will take effect the next time you run the blaze-make command.

example.title: Changing the Blog Title and Subtitle
example.para: To change the blog title to BlazeBlogger and the corresponding subtitle to a CMS without boundaries, type the following commands at a shell prompt:
example.screen: public_html]$ blaze-config blog.title BlazeBlogger The option has been successfully saved. public_html]$ blaze-config blog.subtitle a CMS without boundaries The option has been successfully saved.

section.title: Changing the Blog Metadata
section.para: To change the descrption of the blog, run the following command:
To specify a comma-separated list of keywords that characterize the blog, type:
The changes will take effect the next time you run the blaze-make command.

example.title: Changing the Blog Description and Keywords
example.para: To change the blog description to a CMS without boundaries and keywords to blazeblogger, cms, and blog, type the following at a shell prompt:
example.screen: public_html]$ blaze-config blog.description a CMS without boundaries The option has been successfully saved. public_html]$ blaze-config blog.keywords blazeblogger, cms, blog The option has been successfully saved.

section.title: Changing the Blog Author
section.para: To change the name of the blog author, set the user.name option. For example:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-config user.name Jaromír Hradílek The option has been successfully saved.
section.para: This name appears in the copyright notice, and is used as the default author for a new blog post or page. However, if you prefer to keep the full name in the copyright notice only, you can specify a nickname:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-config user.nickname Blackened The option has been successfully saved.
section.para: Additionally, you can supply an email address to allow readers to contact the blog author directly:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-config user.email jhradilek@gmail.com The option has been successfully saved.
section.para: The changes will take effect the next time you run the blaze-make command.

section.title: Changing the Blog Language
section.para: To allow the use of a non-English translation of the blog, copy an appropriate language file to the .blaze/lang/ directory. For example, in order to enable the Basque translation, type:
section.screen: ~]$ cp /usr/local/share/blazeblogger/lang/eu_ES .blaze/lang/
section.para: To configure the blog to actually use this translation, set the blog.lang accordingly:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-config blog.lang eu_ES The option has been successfully saved.
section.para: The changes will take effect the next time you run the blaze-make command.

section.title: Changing the Blog Theme
section.para: To change the theme of a blog, first extract the content of the theme archive to the directory with .blaze/, for example:
section.screen: ~]$ tar xfz vectorlover-1.0.1.tar.gz
section.para: Then move the template file and the corresponding style sheet to .blaze/theme/ and .blaze/style/ respectively:
section.screen: ~]$ mv vectorlover.html .blaze/theme/ ~]$ mv vectorlover.css .blaze/style/
section.para: Finally, change the configuration to use this theme:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-config blog.theme vectorlover.html The option has been successfully saved. ~]$ blaze-config blog.style vectorlover.css The option has been successfully saved.
section.para: The changes will take effect the next time you run the blaze-make command.

section.title: Adding a Blog Post or a Page
section.para: To write a new blog post, run the following command:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-add
section.para: To write a new page instead, add the --page (or -p) command line option:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-add -p
section.para: This will open an external text editor with a pre-formatted header and brief instructions on how to compose a blog entry. By default, the editor specified by the core.editor configuration option or the EDITOR environment variable is used. To edit the entry in a different edditor, add the --editor (or -E) command line option. For example, to write a blog post in GVim, type:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-add -E "gvim -f"
section.para: The blog post or page header contains important meta data, such as the title, author, or date of publishing of the entry. For a detailed explanation of all available options, refer to .

table.title: A List of Available Header Options

row.entry: Specifies the title of the blog post or page.
Specifies the author of the blog post or page. The value of the user.name (or user.nickname if supplied) configuration option is used by default.
Specifies the date of publishing of the blog post or page, and has to be in the YYYY-MM-DD format. The current date is used by default.
Allows you to specify a comma-separated list of keywords that are specific for the blog post or page.
Allows you to specify a comma-separated list of categories the blog post belongs to. This option is not relevant for pages.
Allows you to specify the string to be used in the URL. It must contain alphanumeric characters, hyphens, and underscores only.

section.para: Besides ordinary elements defined by the HTML or XHTML standard, &PRODUCT; recognizes various special forms that can be used in the text itself. This includes various placeholders that ensure the cross-references within a particular blog are valid and always point to the expected target. For a complete list of these special forms, refer to .

example.screen:
# This and following lines beginning with '#' are the post header. Please # take your time and replace these options with desired values. Just remem- # ber that the date has to be in an YYYY-MM-DD form, tags are a comma sepa- # rated list of categories the post (pages ignore these) belong to, and the # url, if provided, should consist of alphanumeric characters, hyphens and # underscores only. Specifying your own url is especially recommended when # you use non-ASCII characters in your post title. # # title: BlazeBlogger 1.1.1 # author: Jaromír Hradílek # date: 2010-10-30 # keywords: release, bug fix # tags: release # url: # # The header ends here. The rest is the content of your post.

BlazeBlogger 1.1.1 has been released! This release fixes four bugs that may have caused BlazeBlogger to sort entries in a wrong order, produce invalid RSS feed, or not to run properly when using an older version of Perl.

Bug Fixes

  • When the feed.fullposts configuration option was disabled, all HTML/XHTML entities were removed. However, this may have led to an invalid output. With this update, such entities are no longer stripped out, and the RSS feed is now created as expected. (Issue 18, 29)
  • Due to incorrect use of the cmp operator, both blaze-list and blaze-make utilities may have listed blog posts in a wrong order. With this update, the comparison subroutine has been corrected, so that all entries are now sorted in a correct order. (Issue 26)

  • When using an older version of Perl, attempting to run the blaze-make utility may have failed with the following error message:

    blaze-make: Creating `': mkdir : No such file or directory

    This error no longer occurs, and blaze-make now produces the expected output. (Issue 30)

section.title: Editing a Blog Post or a Page
section.para: To edit an existing blog post, run the blaze-edit command followed by its identification number. For example, if you want to edit the blog post with identification number 10, type:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-edit 10
section.para: To edit a page instead, add the --page (or -p) option:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-edit -p 5
section.para: By default, blaze-edit opens a blog post or a page in an external text editor that is specified in the configuration (that is, either in the configuration file, or via the EDITOR environment variable). To use a different text editor, add the --editor (or -E) command line option, for instance:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-edit -E "gvim -f" -p 5
section.para: For a complete list of available command line options, refer to .

section.title: Removing a Blog Post or a Page
section.para: To delete a blog post from your blog, run the blaze-remove command followed by an appropriate identification number:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-remove 10 Successfully removed the post with ID 10.
section.para: To delete a page, add the --page (or -p) command line option:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-remove -p 4 Successfully removed the page with ID 4.
section.para: For a complete list of available command line options, refer to .

warning.para: Be careful when using this command, as there is no easy way to take this action back. To prevent an accidental loss of potentially valuable data, run the command in the interactive mode by supplying the --interactive (or -i) option:
warning.screen: ~]$ blaze-remove -i 10 Remove the post with ID 10 titled `Debian and Fedora Packages'? n Aborted.

section.title: Displaying Blog Statistics
section.para: To display detailed information about the blog statistics, including the total number of blog posts and pages, the date of the very first blog post, and the date of the latest published post, use the blaze-list with the --stats (or shorter -S) option:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-list -S Number of pages: 5 Number of posts: 11 Last post date: 2010-07-25 First post date: 2009-02-10
section.para: You can also display the short version of the above output by supplying the --short (or -s) command line option as well:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-list -Ss There is a total number of 11 blog posts and 5 pages in the repository.

section.title: Listing Blog Posts or Pages
section.para: To make the management of blog posts and pages easier, &PRODUCT; is shipped with the blaze-list utility that allows you to display the content of a blog. This includes the important information such as the identification number, date of publishing, title, and attached tags.

note.para: Since version 0.9.0, &PRODUCT; allows you to enable a colored output for some of its utilities. To enable this feature for blaze-list, use the following command:

section.para: To display all featured blog posts, type the following at a shell prompt:
section.screen:
~]$ blaze-list ID: 11 | 2010-07-05 | Jaromír Hradílek
Title: Join #blazeblogger on IRC Tags: announcement
ID: 10 | 2009-12-16 | Jaromír Hradílek
Title: Debian and Fedora Packages Tags: announcement, archlinux, debian, fedora, ubuntu
etc.
section.para: Similarly, to display the complete list of available pages, add the --pages (or -p) command line option:
section.screen:
~]$ blaze-list -p ID: 5 | 2009-02-10 | Jaromír Hradílek
Title: Downloads
ID: 4 | 2009-02-10 | Jaromír Hradílek
Title: Themes
etc.
section.para: As shown in the examples above, latest entries are listed first by default, and in most cases, this is a reasonable behavior. However, to change the sorting order and display the latest entries last, you can use the --reverse (or -r) option:
section.screen:
~]$ blaze-list -r ID: 1 | 2009-02-10 | Jaromír Hradílek
Title: BlazeBlogger 0.7.0 Tags: release
ID: 2 | 2009-02-11 | Jaromír Hradílek
Title: BlazeBlogger 0.7.1 Tags: release
etc.
section.para: You can also limit the number of listed entries by specifying the --number (or -n) option. For example, to display only the information about the first blog post, type:
section.screen:
~]$ blaze-list -n 1 -r ID: 1 | 2009-02-10 | Jaromír Hradílek
Title: BlazeBlogger 0.7.0 Tags: release
section.para: Additionally, you can limit the output by specifying a blog post author (--author or -a), a tag (--tag or -T), a matching title (--title or -T), a date of publishing, and other criteria. For a complete list of available command line options, refer to .

section.title: Generating a Blog
section.para: To generate a complete directory tree of static pages with all blog posts, single pages, monthly and yearly archives, tags, and an RSS feed, run the following command:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-make Done.
section.para: Unless told otherwise, &PRODUCT; generates the blog in the current working directory. To specify a different location, specify the --destdir (or -d) option. For example, to generate a blog in ~/public_html/, type:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze-make -d ~/public_html Done.
section.para: To display the list of files as they are created, use --verbose (or its short version, -V). For example:
section.screen: ~]$ blaze.make -V Created index.rss Created index.html Created index1.html Created 2010/10/index.html Created 2010/07/11-join-blazeblogger-on-irc/index.html Created 2009/12/10-debian-and-fedora-packages/index.html Created 2009/index.html Created 2010/07/index.html etc. Done.
section.para: For a complete list of available command line options, refer to .

note.para: If you intend your blog to be accessed offline, for example, if you want to review it before you publish it on your website, use the --full-paths (or -F) option:

This option ensures that all generated links point directly to index pages and not to their parent directories. Additionally, you can turn off the creation of the RSS feed as well. To do so, add the --no-rss (or -r) option:

section.title: Displaying a Log
section.para: For the possibility of a future review, &PRODUCT; keeps track of all significant changes to the blog, including its initialization and recovery, addition of new content, changes to existing blog posts and pages, and their removal.

note.para: Since version 0.9.0, &PRODUCT; allows you to enable a colored output for some of its utilites. To enable this feature for blaze-log, use the following command:

section.para: To display the complete history of the blog, type the following at a shell prompt:
section.screen:
~]$ blaze-log Date: Sun Jul 25 16:48:22 2010
Edited the page with ID 5.
Date: Tue Jul 6 18:54:59 2010
Edited the page with ID 5.
etc.
section.para: By default, log entries are sorted from the newest to oldest, so that the latest change is listed at the top. If you prefer the reverse order, use the --reverse (or -r) command line option:
section.screen:
~]$ blaze-log -r Date: Tue Feb 10 00:40:16 2009
Created/recovered a BlazeBlogger repository.
Date: Tue Feb 10 01:06:44 2009
Added the page with ID 1.
etc.
section.para: Finally, to display only a limited number of log entries, use the --number (or -n) command line option. For example, to display the latest change to the blog, type:
section.screen:
~]$ blaze-log -n 1 Date: Sun Jul 25 16:48:22 2010
Edited the page with ID 5.
